North Korean missiles launched over Japan

There have been a number of [North Korean](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea")
missile tests. North Korea has also fired a number of short-range missiles
into the [Sea of Japan](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan "Sea of Japan") [(East Sea of
Korea)](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan_naming_dispute "Sea of Japan naming dispute"), in
what have been interpreted as political gestures.[1][2][3][4]

##
Timeline[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Timeline")]

Year | Information  
---|---  
1976-81 | North Korea commences its missile development program using Scud-B from the Soviet Union and a launchpad from Egypt.[5]  
1984 | First Scud-B missile test firing.[5]  
1988 | Operational deployment of Scud-B and Scud-C missiles.[5]  
1990 | First Rodong missile test.[5]  
1993 | [1993 North Korean missile test](/wiki/1993_North_Korean_missile_test "1993 North Korean missile test") \- (May 29/30, 1993) - [Nodong](/wiki/Nodong "Nodong")  
1998 | North Korea fires off its first ballistic missile, the Unha-1 rocket, also known as the [Taepodong-1](/wiki/Taepodong-1 "Taepodong-1") missile, from the launch site of [Musudan-ri](/wiki/Musudan-ri "Musudan-ri") in North Hamgyong Province.[6]  
1999 | North Korea agrees to a moratorium on long-range missile tests.[7]  
2002 | North Korea pledges to extend moratorium on missile tests beyond 2003.  
2004 | North Korea reaffirms moratorium.[8]  
2005 | North Korea fires short-range missile into Sea of Japan.[9]  
2006 | [2006 North Korean missile test](/wiki/2006_North_Korean_missile_test "2006 North Korean missile test") \- (July 5, 2006) - [Taepodong-2](/wiki/Taepodong-2 "Taepodong-2") failed [6]  
2009 | Failed orbit of the [Kwangmyongsong-2](/wiki/Kwangmyongsong-2 "Kwangmyongsong-2") satellite aboard an [Unha-2](/wiki/Unha "Unha") carrier rocket (April 5, 2009)  
2009 | [2009 North Korean missile test](/wiki/2009_North_Korean_missile_test "2009 North Korean missile test") (July 4, 2009)  
2012 | Failed launch of the [Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3](/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng-3 "Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3") satellite aboard an [Unha-3](/wiki/Unha "Unha") carrier rocket (April 13, 2012)  
2012 | Successful launch of the [Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2](/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng-3_Unit_2 "Kwangmyŏngsŏng-3 Unit 2") satellite aboard a three stage rocket (December 12, 2012)[6]  
2013 | [2013 North Korean missile tests](/wiki/2013_Korean_crisis#Missiles_launches.2C_agreements.2C_and_ship_confrontation "2013 Korean crisis") (May 18–20, 2013 - part of [2013 Korean crisis](/wiki/2013_Korean_crisis "2013 Korean crisis"))  
2014 | [2014 North Korean missile tests](/wiki/2014_North_Korean_missile_tests "2014 North Korean missile tests") (March 2014) including [Nodong](/wiki/Nodong "Nodong"), success[10]  
2015 | North Korea claims to launch a missile from a submarine (May 2015)[11][6]  
2016 | Successful launch of the [Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4](/wiki/Kwangmy%C5%8Fngs%C5%8Fng-4 "Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4") satellite (February 7, 2016)  
2016 | Test of engine designed for an [intercontinental ballistic missile](/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile "Intercontinental ballistic missile") (April 2016)[12]  
2016 | North Korea claims to launch a [Pukkuksong-1](/wiki/Pukkuksong-1 "Pukkuksong-1")[13] missile capable of striking the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") (August 2016).[14] The missile is a [Submarine-launched ballistic missile](/wiki/Submarine-launched_ballistic_missile "Submarine-launched ballistic missile").[14]  
2016 | Failed North Korean ballistic missile launch (October 15, 2016)- [15]  
2016 | Failed launch of an intermediate-range missile (October 19, 2016)[16]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired a [Pukguksong-2](/wiki/Pukguksong-2 "Pukguksong-2") missile over the Sea of Japan. This was the first launch of the new [medium-range ballistic missile](/wiki/Medium-range_ballistic_missile "Medium-range ballistic missile") (February 11, 2017).[17][18][6]  
2017 | North Korea launches four ballistic missiles from the [Tongchang-ri](/wiki/Tongchang-ri "Tongchang-ri") launch site in the northwest.[19] Some flew 620 mi (1,000 km) before falling into the [Sea of Japan](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan "Sea of Japan"). (March 6, 2017)[20][6]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired a medium-range ballistic missile from its eastern port of [Sinpo](/wiki/Sinpo "Sinpo") into the Sea of Japan (April 4, 2017)[21][22][6]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired an unidentified land-based missile from the [naval base](/wiki/Naval_base "Naval base") in [Sinpo](/wiki/Sinpo "Sinpo") but it exploded almost immediately after the [takeoff](/wiki/Takeoff "Takeoff") (April 15, 2017).[23][24][25][26]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired an unidentified missile from [Pukchang](/wiki/Pukchang "Pukchang") airfield (April 28, 2017).[27][28] Missile, believed to be a medium-range[29] KN-17 ballistic missile,[27] falters and breaks apart minutes after liftoff.[29][30]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired a [Hwasong-12](/wiki/Hwasong-12 "Hwasong-12")[31] missile from a test site in the area of [Kusong](/wiki/Kusong "Kusong") (May 13, 2017).[32] The missile, later revealed to be an [intermediate range ballistic missile](/wiki/Intermediate_range_ballistic_missile "Intermediate range ballistic missile"),[33] traveled 30 minutes,[34] reached an altitude of more than 2,111.5 km, and flew a horizontal distance of 789 km (489 miles), before falling into the Sea of Japan.[33] Such a missile would have a range of at least 4,000, reaching Guam, to 6,000 km.[32][31]  
2017 | North Korea test-fired another [Pukguksong-2](/wiki/Pukguksong-2 "Pukguksong-2") medium-range ballistic missile from Pukchang airfield (May 21, 2017),[35][36] which traveled approximately 300 miles before falling into the Sea of Japan.[37] The missile landed about 217 miles from North Korea's east coast.[37]  
2017 | North Korea fired a Short Range Ballistic Missile into the [Sea of Japan](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan "Sea of Japan") (May 29, 2017). It traveled 450 km.[38]  
2017 | North Korea fired several missiles into the [Sea of Japan](/wiki/Sea_of_Japan "Sea of Japan") (June 8, 2017). They are believed to be [anti-ship missiles](/wiki/Anti-ship_missile "Anti-ship missile").[39] The South Korean military said the launches show the reclusive regime's "precise targeting capability."  
2017 | North Korea tested a new [rocket engine](/wiki/Rocket_engine "Rocket engine") that could possibly be fitted to an intercontinental ballistic missile (June 23, 2017).[40]  
2017 | North Korea tested its first [intercontinental ballistic missile](/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile "Intercontinental ballistic missile") (ICBM) named [Hwasong-14](/wiki/Hwasong-14 "Hwasong-14") on July 4.[41][42] It launched from the Panghyon Aircraft Factory 8 km southeast of [Panghyon Airport](/wiki/Panghyon_Airport "Panghyon Airport").[43] It was aimed straight up at a lofted trajectory and reached more than 2,500 km into space.[44] It landed 37 minutes later,[45] more than 930 km from its launch site,[46] into Japan's exclusive economic zone.[47] Aiming long, the missile would have traveled 7,000-8,000 km or more, reaching Alaska, Hawaii, and maybe Seattle.[45][48][49][50][51] Its operational range would be farther, bringing a 500 kg payload to targets in most of the contiguous United States 9,700 km away.[52][53][54]  
2017 | The 14th missile test carried out by North Korea in 2017 was another ICBM launched at 23:41 North Korea time (15:41 GMT) from [Chagang Province](/wiki/Chagang_Province "Chagang Province") in the north of the country on July 28, 2017. Los Angeles, Denver, Chicago, Boston, and New York appear to be within range.[55] The missile's reentry vehicle (RV) was seen by people in Japan as it entered the atmosphere and landed near the northernmost Japanese island, Hokkaido.[56][57] Analysis later revealed that the RV broke up on re-entry; further testing would be required.[58] The CIA made an assessment expecting adequate performance of the RV under the different stresses of a shallower trajectory towards the continental US.[59]  
2017 | North Korea test fires three short range ballistic missiles from the Kangwon province on August 26. Two travel approximately 250 kilometers in a northeastern direction and one explodes immediately after launch.[60]  
2017 | On August 29, 2017, at 6 AM local time, North Korea [launched a ballistic missile over Northern Japan](/wiki/North_Korean_August_2017_missile_launch_over_Japan "North Korean August 2017 missile launch over Japan").[61] The missile's short and low trajectory and its breakup into three pieces is consistent with the failure of a heavy [post-boost vehicle](/wiki/Multiple_independently_targetable_reentry_vehicle "Multiple independently targetable reentry vehicle").[62]  
2017 | North Korea launched a ballistic missile on September 15 from Sunan airfield. It reached a height of 770 km and flew a distance of 3,700 km for 17 minutes over Hokkaido before landing in the Pacific.[63]

6 | [September 15, 2017](/wiki/September_2017_North_Korean_missile_launch_over_Japan "September 2017 North Korean missile launch over Japan") | [Hwasong-12](/wiki/Hwasong-12 "Hwasong-12") | [Hokkaido](/wiki/Hokkaido_Prefecture "Hokkaido Prefecture") | No | Missile launch | N/A  
  
## Events related to Missile
Tests[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Events related to Missile Tests")]

###
2016[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 2016")]

On February 7, 2016, roughly a month after an [alleged hydrogen bomb
test](/wiki/January_2016_North_Korean_nuclear_test "January 2016 North Korean
nuclear test"), North Korea claimed to have put a [satellite](/wiki/Satellite
"Satellite") into [low Earth orbit](/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit "Low Earth orbit").
[Japanese Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan "Prime Minister of
Japan") [Shinzō Abe](/wiki/Shinz%C5%8D_Abe "Shinzō Abe") had warned the North
to not launch the rocket, and if it did and the rocket violated
[Japanese](/wiki/Japan "Japan") territory, it would be shot down.
Nevertheless, North Korea launched the rocket anyway, claiming the satellite
was purely intended for peaceful, scientific purposes. Several nations,
including the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), Japan, and
[South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea"), have criticized the launch,
and despite North Korean claims that the rocket was for peaceful purposes, it
has been heavily criticized as an attempt to perform an
[ICBM](/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile "Intercontinental ballistic
missile") test under the guise of a peaceful satellite launch.
[China](/wiki/China "China") also criticized the launch, however urged "the
relevant parties" to "refrain from taking actions that may further escalate
tensions on the Korean peninsula".[64]

While some North Korean pronouncements have been treated with skepticism and
ridicule, analysts treated the unusual pace of North Korean rocket and nuclear
testing in early 2016 quite seriously. Admiral Bill Gortney, head of the
[North American Aerospace Defense
Command](/wiki/North_American_Aerospace_Defense_Command "North American
Aerospace Defense Command"), told Congress in March 2016, "It's the prudent
decision on my part to assume that [Kim Jong Un] has the capability to
miniaturize a nuclear weapon and put it on an ICBM," suggesting a major shift
from a few years earlier.[65]

North Korea appeared to launch a missile test from a submarine on April 23,
2016; while the missile only traveled 30 km, one U.S. analyst noted that
"North Korea's sub launch capability has gone from a joke to something very
serious".[66] North Korea conducted multiple missile tests in 2016.[67]

###
2017[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_North_Korean_missile_tests&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 2017")]

On August 29, 2017 United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres has
condemned the latest North Korea Ballistic Missile Launch and termed it as
violation of relevant UN Security Council resolutions, as According to press
reports, early Tuesday morning, the North Korea Ballistic Missile travelled
some 2,700 kilometers, flying over Japan before crashing into the Pacific
Ocean.[68]

On September 3, 2017, North Korea claimed to have successfully tested a
thermonuclear bomb, also known as a hydrogen bomb. Corresponding seismic
activity similar to an earthquake of magnitude 6.3 was reported by the
[USGS](/wiki/USGS "USGS") making the blast around 10 times more powerful than
previous detonations by the country.[69] Later the bomb yield was estimated to
be 250 kilotons, based on further study of the seismic data.[70] The test was
reported to be "a perfect success".[71]
